conclusion: Determine the resultant Ampere force on the three resistance wires of the equilateral triangular conductor frame.
The frame is placed perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field, and points A and B are connected to a power supply with constant voltage.
The current passing through the wire generates an Ampere force due to the interaction with the magnetic field.
The Ampere force (Lorentz force) on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by the formula: F = I · L · B · sin(θ).
Since the wire is perpendicular to the magnetic field, θ = 90° and sin(90°) = 1.
In an equilateral triangle, all sides are equal, and all angles are 60°.
The current from the power supply splits at point A and flows through the wires AC and AB, dividing equally due to symmetry and equal resistance.
Similarly, the current from point B splits equally between BC and BA.
The force on segment AB is given as F.
Due to symmetry and equal current distribution, the force on segment AC and BC will also be F.
The direction of the force on each wire segment can be determined using the right-hand rule.
Since the magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the triangle, the forces will be directed outward from the center of the triangle.
The forces on AC and BC are directed at 60° angles relative to AB.
To find the resultant force, we need to add these vectorially.
The horizontal components of the forces on AC and BC will cancel each other due to symmetry.
The vertical components will add up.
The vertical component of the force on AC is F · sin(60°) = F · √3/2.
The vertical component of the force on BC is also F · √3/2.
The total vertical component is F · √3/2 + F · √3/2 = F · √3.
The resultant force on the triangular frame is the sum of the force on AB and the combined vertical components of the forces on AC and BC: F_resultant = F + F · √3.
The magnitude of the resultant Ampere force on the three resistance wires is F · (1 + √3).
